resources.string: In Java, loops are useful to allow the execution of a set of statements or methods repeatedly. In all cases, executions are continued when a testing condition evaluates to true and terminated when the Boolean value of the condition returns false. Therefore, it is vital to include the condition in the loop or else it would not work! \n\nThere are three main types of loop execution which provide a similar basic functionality but differ in their syntax and when they check the condition evaluation.
The components of the loop include:

• INITIALIZATION CONDITION: 
The variable is initialized here. A previously declared variable can be used or a new variable is declared, local to the loop. 

• TESTING CONDITION: 
The testing condition must return a Boolean value. The loop is executed until the testing condition returns ‘false’. The condition is checked before the execution of loop statements. 

• INCREMENT/DECREMENT: 
Updates the declared variable for the next iteration. 

• STATEMENT(S): 
Once the condition returns a Boolean value of true, the statement in the loop body is executed.

Repeats the execution statements based on a testing condition which once again, should return a Boolean value of true. It can also be thought as a repeating ‘if’ statement! \n\nThe while loop is considered an event-controlled condition and should be used when the number of iterations is not known, relying the amount of repetitions on the satisfaction of the condition.

• TESTING CONDITION: 
The condition is checked before execution of loop statements. 

• STATEMENT(S): 
The body of the loop is executed when the boolean condition returns true. The statements should contain an updated value for the variable, usually an increment/decrement for the following iteration.

• STATEMENT(S): 
The loop begins with an execution of the statement. Once again, this should include an updated value for the variable of an increment/decrement for the following iteration. 

• TESTING CONDITION: 
The condition is checked after execution of loop statements. If it returns ‘true’, the next iteration starts.
